image.alt: Adobe Logo

cards.title: Adobe
cards.shortDescription: Work with other engineers on the libraries team to develop comprehensive features and ensure smooth integration into other Adobe products.
cards.description:
A brief description of CC Libraries

Creative Cloud Libraries is a panel that exists within most applications at Adobe that allows designers to have a single source of truth for their assets.

The example I always like to use is this — Imagine that you’re working as a designer at ESPN, and you want to make a graphic promoting the Cleveland Browns vs the Chicago Bears on Monday Night Football. In order to make that easily, you’ll need the logos, colors, and fonts for each team along with the logos, colors, and fonts used for Monday Night Football. This can be an annoying process, as each time you’d have to hunt down the correct information from each team, or import all the assets from a shared dropbox.

Libraries makes this process easier, as it allows for you to create a library containing assets you’d need and share them with the people that will need it. Coming back to our example, there could be a shared library that contains every NFL team’s logo, colors, and fonts that would be shared amongst designers at ESPN. There could also be a shared library containing anything that is consistently used to make Monday Night Football graphics as well. So instead of having a designer hunt down these assets themselves, they would just easily find these assets in a library.

My Experience with the Team

The Libraries team is a very unique team within Adobe, as it is an independent team integrating the libraries panel into other Adobe applications. This means that the libraries panel has to do the job of mimicking the surrounding application that the panel is hosted in, both in style and functionality. This adds an extra layer of complexity to development, as making anything for the panel requires testing changes in at least a few different application to make sure it works as expected. That said, it is an extremely fun and rewarding experience to understand what value I am bringing to the customer with what I am developing, especially with my personal experience using the product.

image.alt: Speedway Motors

cards.title: Speedway Motors
cards.shortDescription: Develop and maintain the Speedway Motors ecommerce website using .NET and React.js.
cards.description:
My internship at Speedway is a little different than most internships. Instead of being given a project and using the full-time developers as resources, I was a fully-integrated team member that participates in completing regular issues. This meant I was an active participant in common agile processes such as stand ups, sprint planning meetings, and postmortems. I worked on the frontend-focused team, so I mostly focused on getting backend information from .NET and displaying it well using React.js. However, I got a wide variety of issues such as:
  • Find a bug in an image file processor / optimizer, where the image thumbnail does not display.
  • Add a sliding animation to a product carousel when the user interacts with the carousel.
  • Implement the LogRocket tracking pixel onto the site for UX help & debugging information.
  • Help create the design framework for the server-side rendered footer.

table.languages: React.js, Redux, Enzyme, Jest, HTML/CSS, Javascript, .NET, C#

image.alt: PMG Digital Marketing Agency

cards.title: PMG Digital Marketing Agency
cards.shortDescription: Created custom, targeted, dynamic advertisements for companies like Madewell and Old Navy.
cards.description:
My main accomplishment at PMG was to create a Dynamic+ Banner generator, which wired a basic product feed to a customizable template for a Dynamic+ Banner.

What are Dynamic+ Banners?

Let’s say a person — let’s call her Sally — wants to buy a pair of long black socks. She wants to order this pair of socks online at StoreA’s online website. To do this, she hops on Google Chrome, visits StoreA’s website, and finds a good pair of black socks on the site. However, she gets distracted by something else and ends up going off of the page to do something else. A few days later, Sally is visiting one of her favorite blogs when an advertisement appears on the sidebar from StoreA. In this advert, she sees the same pair of socks as before, along with a few other similar pairs of socks!

What Sally just saw was a dynamic+ advertisement. When Sally visited StoreA’s site, StoreA was able to use a tracking pixel to figure out what products Sally viewed. StoreA took a product that they know Sally is interested in and showed them an advertisement that includes that same product. This specific process is called retargeting, since companies are just showing information that they know already exists.

My Dynamic+ Banner Generator

Dynamic+ Banners are a feature that is provided to a large variety of clients that PMG serves, such as Madewell, Old Navy, Ralph Lauren, and many other high-profile companies. Before this tool was made, a developer at PMG had to go in and manually create every one of the 7 or 8 sizes of dynamic banner, and manually hook up the feed to customize the banner and the feed to display custom products. The even more frustrating thing is that the process could easily be automated, since PMG provided a number of templates when presenting Dynamic+ Advertisements to companies. Therefore, many of the banners looked very similar, with only a few customization tweaks made by the company.

The generator I created was a Node.js command line tool. My generator solved that issue by providing both an easy way to generate the basic templates, along with the flexibility to make tweaks to an individual project based on client-specific feedback. It allowed for all of the different banner sizes to use the same Javascript file, so a change to the feed didn’t have to be copied over 7 or 8 times. It also generated zips in the correct format to easily upload to Google Studio (formerly known as Doubleclick Studio). I also created one of the templates for the Dynamic+ banner, so you know who to blame if you get a Madewell ad in the future :).

Overall, my tool allowed for Dynamic+ Banners to be made much more quickly, allowing developers to focus more on productive tasks. I learned a lot about Node, HTML/CSS, and a lot about how the advertising world works.

table.languages: Node.js, Javascript, HTML/CSS, Google Studio (Formerly known as Doubleclick Studio)

image.alt: Chemistry of Ice

cards.title: UNL Chemistry Department
cards.shortDescription: Created websites using the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Web Framework. Collaborated closely with Nebraska professors to deliver a webiste that met their needs.
cards.description:
My primary job at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln chemistry department website was to update the various pages of the site to either add new content or update the pages to look better. I would work very closely with professors and faculty in the department, so I got good at setting expectations, and giving an accurate scope of how long a specific project would take. The editing of websites themselves was done strictly by changing the HTML through Drupal, so I had no access to the stylesheet or any scripts. Most of the time I didn’t need either of those, since the University has a pretty extensive web framework that made my job much easier. However, I often times found weird workaround solutions to my problems that required adding my own script tag or style tag.

My other job was to create / update the Colloquium graphics for the semester. I designed a template for the colloquium graphics using Adobe Illustrator, and was expected to maintain the TV screens in the chemistry building to display the correct information at all times.

Overall, I learned a lot about HTML, but my most valuable experience I got out of this job was to manage and set the expectations of others, and to work with clients to get to them what they want.

image.alt: University of Nebraska-Lincoln Campus

cards.title: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
cards.shortDescription:
GPA: 3.839
Dean's list from Spring 2018 through Spring 2021 (7 semesters)

image.alt: Peyton Tanzillo hiding behind a bush.

cards.shortDescription:
Welcome to my website!

My name is Peyton Tanzillo, and I am a Software Engineer currently working Adobe.

I am a motivated web developer with an eye for design and a drive to create. I am constantly exploring, and I’m not afraid to venture out of my comfort zone to learn new things.

Outside of work, you’ll likely find me playing video games or trying to find new ways to create. I am a huge fan of indie games like Ori and the Blind Forest, Hollow Knight, Transistor, Omori, and a lot more! I have played Rocket League semi-competitively, and have participated on teams both at the University of Nebraska and at Adobe. On top of that, I’m one of those people that still plays Minecraft on a regular basis, and I’d be happy to show off my past builds if you’re somehow interested. Outside of video games, I have been exploring music production, video production, 3d modeling, and even a bit of game development! I don’t feel like I’m good at any of that yet, but it’s been fun to mess around and try to translate what is in my head to the real world.

Anyways, that’s about it as far as getting to know me. If you have any questions or want to reach out to me feel free to email me at peytontanzillo@icloud.com. Have a great day!

cards.title: This Website

image.alt: A picture of this website!

cards.shortDescription: An adaptive website that changes the color scheme based on which website was passed in. For example, the link peytontanzillo.com/crazypants/projects will change this page to look super crazy!

table.languages: React (including Redux, Jest, Enzyme), HTML, CSS, Javascript

cards.description:
Why did I make this website?

I wanted to improve upon my first attempt at making a website, which was thrown together one weekend to reflect my resumé. I really liked my old website, however I ran into a lot of issues when I tried to start maintaining the website, and I learned more and more about modern web development:
  • The website was difficult to maintain, as I would need to study and understand my old code in order to do it.
  • The technologies I used for the site are old for web development.
  • There was no logic behind the code, so it was a better showcase of graphic design skills rather than coding tech.
I decided to get to work making a new website, and I learned a lot doing so.

What is different about this website?

The basic concept of this website is that I’d be able to create a customized web experience for every single company I applied for. Since I was submitting a resumé to a lot of companies, I wanted to make this customization easy on my end, so I wouldn’t have to spend an unnecessary amount of work time getting something to look good. The easiest way to do this, in my eyes, was to change the colors of the website to match the colors of the company I was applying to. That way I have control over the shape and layout of my website, but I can reach that goal.

The content on the website (including the specific themes) is controlled through json files, so I wouldn’t run into the problem I had before where I found it difficult to maintain the website. This time, if I wanted to make a change to the site, it was as easy as saving a change to my json file and pushing it to my repository. In fact, I’ve made a large number of changes to the website since initially publishing it to my domain.

Overall, this was one of the most fun project I have worked on, and I had a really good time figuring out applying my new React knowledge and learning how to use contexts in a meaningful way.

cards.title: Minecraft Plugins

image.alt: A picture of the boat racing hub on a Minecraft server I play often.

cards.shortDescription: As a side hobby I've been recently helping with the development and maintainance of various Minecraft plugins, most notably a racing plugin!
cards.description:
My racing plugin is my most extensive plugin so I’m just going to talk about that here. As a fair warning, I will be talking about various game mechanics and assuming you have a basic understanding of what Minecraft is and the items and mechanics that Minecraft has. If you don’t a lot of this may end up being quite confusing.

The origins of my racing plugin started on my creative server. I am participating in a survival server with a bunch of my friends, and I was looking for a new project to start working on. I had heard that you can make race tracks by allowing boats to slide on ice, so I ended up spending a night throwing together a pretty simple layout just to see if it was any fun and it was worth pursuing. Turns out — yes — as evidenced by staying up until 2am that night trying to beat my times using my phone’s stopwatch to time myself. The next day I brought a friend onto my server, and we ended up setting up a small ingame timer and spending that night as well trying to compete for the best times we could. As time went on and my friends and I got more and more into getting the best times, I thought I’d apply my coding skills and make a plugin that can record times and save them so that my friends and I could compete for the best scores independently of each other.

That led me down a long path starting with a simple timing plugin for my placeholder racing track, and continuing with a comprehensive plugin for all forms of Minecraft racing. As of now, my plugin can handle checkpoints, splits, leaderboards, and also handle its own multiplayer races so that my friends and I could fairly race against each other.

Overall, this has been a really fun side project to work on, and I’m looking forward to seeing where this continues to take me!

cards.title: Pente Web

image.alt: A picture of the pente web project.

cards.shortDescription: A makeover of a board game I love playing called Pente! Think of it as advanced, strategic, tic-tac-toe.

table.languages: React (including Redux, Jest, Enzyme), HTML, CSS, Javascript

cards.description:
This project was my first ever experience with React.js, which is why it looks suspiciously like a more advanced version of the React tutorial :). It was honestly the perfect way to get into modern frameworks of web development, and I learned a lot from messing around with this project!

Features:
  • Scorekeeping & win screen
  • Color picker for each team, so somebody can change colors if they want to.
  • Undo move (up to 2), so you can give somebody who made a terrible mistake some leeway.

cards.title: Softie Startup
cards.subtitle: Fall 2020 and Spring 2021

image.alt: Grouve

cards.shortDescriptionSubtitle: An event planning tool with playlist integration
cards.shortDescription:
A project with 8 other software engineering majors in which we were taught the basics of making out own software product and researching its usefulness.
The logo shown here is a logo actually designed by me, with help from Maggie Harder.
cards.description:
Softie Startup

Softie startup was an initiative spearheaded by my classmates and I as a potential option to having a second year of our Senior Design class. We felt that since we were going through the same curriculum, we did not feel like we were getting any new information out of the class again. Our solution was to have a self-starting version of the class that allowed us to learn more about creating our own products and have more freedom over what we end up creating. The proposal ended up working, and I, along with 8 other students, ended up being the guinea pigs for this new idea.

Phase 1: Exploration

For our first semester, we came up with three potential ideas — and did market research on the different ideas to determine wether they were viable and worth moving forward with. We conducted interviews, sent out questionnaires, and generally asked around to see if people had a real interest in the product. Once that was done, we got together as a full team and, based on our research, selected one project to move forward with, which was Grouve!

Phase 2: Building

For our second semester, we were tasked to work on building the project as a team. I worked as a UX designer and QA engineer for the team. I helped design a user flow using Adobe XD, and test that flow on potential users of our product. I also set up a testing framework so that other devs could easily mock expected data, and wrote tests for the project others were building.

cards.title: Senior Design
cards.subtitle: Fall 2019 and Spring 2020

image.alt: Peyton Tanzillo hiding behind a bush.

cards.shortDescriptionSubtitle: A smart scheduling tool for recurring events.
cards.shortDescription:
We worked closely with a sponsor to execute his vision of a new scheduling product.
This was a group project with Max Danley, Taher Ahmed, Jesse Reyes-Cortez, David Garza, and Rinish Reddy.
cards.description:
Senior Design

Senior Design is a year-long class where a group of 6 Computer Science / Software Engineering students work with a company as software developers, similar to an internship. The students are expected to follow agile methodologies and focus on communicating with sponsors effectively. I chose to take on a leadership position, and so my focus for this project was more on making sure everyone followed Agile, and working on our development environment.

The Regular Phil App

Our sponsor was the Regular Phil App. To be blunt, this project started out very much like a startup. Henry, our sponsor, had an idea for an app, and paid for us to execute his idea. The basic idea for the app was that it was like a smart scheduling app. The app would take an input of people, possible times, and possible event titles and set up a poll that gets sent to that list of people, then chooses the best event and creates a calendar invite for that best event. It also incorporates some NLP so that the bot can understand anything that is sent in the group chat and adjust accordingly.

cards.title: Software Security
cards.subtitle: Fall 2019

image.alt: Peyton Tanzillo hiding behind a bush.

cards.shortDescription:
An experiment to test the viability of a grid-based password compared to a traditional string password.
This was a group project with Jacob Orellana.
cards.description: The visual password we created was an experiment that we conducted for a software security class to find an alternative to the traditional string password. The basic concept was that, with a grid-based password, we can make a blank space its own set of characters that can make passwords harder to decipher, longer, and stronger. We conducted our own study that showed that users were more likely to remember these grid passwords, rather than a newly created string password. However, we found that the grid password was extremely annoying and frustrating for users to use, and and the time it took to enter their password was around 3x longer than that of a normal password. Overall, it was an interesting experiment that gave us some insight into the challenges of the interfaces behind software security.

cards.title: Human Computer Interaction
cards.subtitle: Fall 2018

image.alt: Peyton Tanzillo hiding behind a bush.

cards.shortDescription:
A web service that conglomerates movies and tv shows (on Netflix, Hulu etc.) all in one place.
This was a group project with Joey Ballentine, Samir Kashyap, and Braydon Clyde.
Since we were only testing for human interaction with the software, the project is just a proof-of-concept demo.
cards.description: This was a prototype for a class called Human Computer Interaction. This was the demo that we showed to users of a streaming platform aggregator, so people don’t have to search across different platforms to find a show they want to watch. This was a user interface where we made a wireframe, a mockup, and then a prototype and tested it on users.
